importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the report's publication, indicating when the public received the preliminary findings from the National Transportation Safety Board regarding the crash of Brett James' plane.
The year when Brett James co-wrote 'Jesus, Take the Wheel' for Carrie Underwood's debut album, marking a pivotal moment in his career and the broader country music industry.
The date of the fatal plane crash in Franklin, North Carolina, which resulted in the deaths of all three people on board and prompted a safety review by the NTSB.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period between the crash on September 18, 2025, and the public release of the NTSB preliminary report on October 20, 2025, highlights the timeline of investigation and public awareness.

keyTakeAways: The plane operated by Grammy-winning songwriter Brett James entered a 'tightening spiral' before crashing on September 18, 2025, killing all three people on board.
James was flying a Cirrus SR22T single-engine plane on a visual approach to runway 7 in Franklin, North Carolina, approximately 270 miles southeast of Nashville.

Air traffic control had approved a visual approach, but James failed to change to the common traffic advisory frequency and continued to announce his position at 6,800 feet with a planned 360-degree turn.

The controller attempted to communicate that James had not changed the radio frequency, but there were no further communications from the pilot before the plane flew over the runway and entered a spiral descent.
The NTSB report found no mechanical issues in the aircraft wreckage, suggesting the crash resulted from pilot error or communication failure.

Brett James was a highly respected songwriter, having collaborated with Taylor Swift, Bon Jovi, Keith Urban, and Kenny Chesney, and his work on 'Jesus, Take the Wheel' helped launch Carrie Underwood’s career.

namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A Grammy-winning songwriter and music industry collaborator
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Brett James is the central figure in the crash, as he was piloting the plane that crashed and was one of the most sought-after songwriters in country music.

namedEntities.name: National Transportation Safety Board (NTSB)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A U.S. federal agency responsible for investigating transportation accidents
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The NTSB conducted and released a preliminary report on the crash, providing official findings on the cause and contributing factors.

namedEntities.name: Cirrus SR22T
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The specific plane model involved in the crash, which the NTSB examined for mechanical issues, which were found to be absent.

namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The crash site is geographically significant, placing the incident about 270 miles southeast of Nashville, linking it to regional aviation and air traffic patterns.

namedEntities.name: Runway 7
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A designated runway at the airport in Franklin, North Carolina
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The intended landing runway, which the plane approached before descending into a spiral and crashing.

namedEntities.name: Common Traffic Advisory Frequency (CTAF)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A radio frequency used by pilots to report position when no air traffic control tower is present
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: James failed to tune to CTAF, violating standard aviation protocol and contributing to the loss of communication with air traffic control.

namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A song co-written by Brett James and Hillary Lindsay and Gordie Sampson

summaryOfNewsArticle: A preliminary report from the National Transportation Safety Board revealed that Grammy-winning songwriter Brett James, 57, died in a plane crash on September 18, 2025, when his Cirrus SR22T aircraft entered a 'tightening spiral' after failing to maintain proper communication with air traffic control. The plane, flying on a visual approach to runway 7 in Franklin, North Carolina, did not switch to the common traffic advisory frequency (CTAF), despite being instructed to do so. James announced his position at 6,800 feet and intended a 360-degree turn, but the controller noted the radio frequency had not changed. No mechanical issues were found in the aircraft. Brett James was a highly influential songwriter, known for his collaborations with Taylor Swift, Bon Jovi, Keith Urban, and Kenny Chesney, including co-writing 'Jesus, Take the Wheel' for Carrie Underwood's debut album in 2005, which became a landmark in country music.
title: Songwriter Brett James’ Plane Crashes After Communication Error, NTSB Reports
